rows.title: Why should we keep our food safe?
rows.text: People become infected with intestinal worms (also known as parasitic helminths) by eating unsafe food. Diseases such as typhoid fever (bacteria infection) can also happen by eating unsafe food or water.
rows.reference:
Baby WASH Programming. UNICEF Eastern and Southern Africa: UNICEF; 2020.  

Extract;
People become infected with intestinal parasitic worms (also known as helminths) by eating contaminated food or through contact with contaminated soil. 

Diseases such as typhoid fever – a bacterial infection – are also caused by ingesting contaminated food or water.

rows.title: The five keys to keeping your food safe
rows.text:
* Keep clean.
* Separate raw and cooked food.  
* Cook thoroughly.
* Keep food at a safe temperature. 
* Use safe water and raw materials.
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.

rows.title: Keep Clean
rows.text:
* Handwash before and during touching food for cooking.
* Don't forget as well to wash your hands after going to the toilet.
* Clean your cooking space and tools.
* Keep bugs, pests, and other animals away from the cooking area.  
* Cover food if you can and use nets to keep away bugs!
rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
Keep Clean
i. Wash your hands before handling food and often during food preparation
ii. Wash your hands after going to the toilet
iii. Wash and sanitize all surfaces and equipment used for food preparation
iv. Protect kitchen areas and food from insects, pests, and other animals
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.

rows.title: Separate raw and cooked
rows.text:
* Don't use the knife used to cut raw meat, chicken, and seafood to cut other foods before washing.
* Store food in containers where you can!  This will keep it safe from pests, moisture, rot, and also to stop mixing of raw and prepared foods.
rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
Separate raw and cooked
i.  Separate raw meat, poultry, and seafood from other foods
ii.  Use separate equipment and utensils, such as  knives and cutting boards, for handling raw foods
iii.  Store food in containers to avoid contact between raw and prepared foods
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.

rows.title: Cook thoroughly
rows.text:
* Clean up your ingredients, especially raw meat.
* Cook food thoroughly, especially meat, chicken, eggs, and seafood.  For meat and chicken, check that their juice is clear rather than pink or bloody. 
* When making stews, remember to bring them to a boil.
* Reheat cooked food thoroughly.
* Boil water used to make baby foods and drinks.
rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
i. Cook food thoroughly, especially meat, poultry, eggs, and seafood
ii. Bring food like soups and stews to boil to make sure they have reached 70 degrees Celsius. For meat and poultry, make sure that juices are clear, not pink. Ideally, use a thermometer.
iii. Reheat cooked food thoroughly
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.

rows.title: Keep food at a safe temperature
rows.text:
* Don't eat cooked food that has been left out for more than two hours.
* Keep cooked food really hot before feeding your family.
rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
Keep food at a safe temperature
i. Do not leave cooked food at room temperature for more than 2 hours
ii. Refrigerate promptly all cooked food and food that can go bad
(preferably below 5 degrees Celsius)
iii.  Keep cooked food piping hot (more than 60°C) prior to serving
iv. Do not store food too long even in the refrigerator
v. Do not thaw frozen food at room temperature
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.

rows.title: Use safe water and raw materials
rows.text:
*  Use safe water (see our modules on water for more tips).  Even though your water might look clean, it's still important to treat it.
*  Remember to wash your fruits and vegetables.
rows.reference:
5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  Geneva: WHO; 2016.

Extract
i. Use safe water or treat it to make it safe
ii. Select fresh and wholesome foods 
iii. Choose foods processed for safety, such as pasteurized milk
iv. Wash fruits and vegetables, especially if eaten raw
v. Do not use food beyond its expiry date
rows.reference_link_title: 5 Keys to Safer Food Manual.  WHO; 2006.
